abstract: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, found himself in a lively debate with the chairwoman of the Congressional Oversight Panel over the reasons it was the only big bank that needed two huge government bailouts in the fall of 2008.
snippet: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, found himself in a lively debate with the chairwoman of the Congressional Oversight Panel over the reasons it was the only big bank that needed two huge government bailouts in the fall of 2008.
lead_paragraph: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup‘s chief executive, has little love for short-sellers. He told the Congressional Oversight Panel on Thursday that they were in part responsible for the bank’s near-collapse in the fall of 2008 and that they exploited “fear” to make money by betting that Citi’s stock price would keep falling.

headline.main: Is Citi Special? Pandit Blames Short-Sellers
